H2.text: when did they stop saying mass in latin. 1900

H3.text: when did they stop saying mass in latin. 1967

A4.text: the use of the Latin language is to be preserved in the Latin rites.

A5.text: the current official text in Latin is that in the third typical edition of the Roman Missal, published in 2002 and reprinted with corrections and updating in 2008.

A6.text: the Order of the Mass contains a 1970 Latin text.

A7.text: the Order of the Mass contains a 1973 English translation.

A8.text: Mass of Paul VI in Latin

A10.text: The Tridentine Mass, ... was the most widely used Eucharistic liturgy in the world from its issuance in 1570 until its replacement by the Mass of Paul VI promulgated in 1969.

A11.text: In 1958, permission was given for Hindi to be used at masses in India.

A12.text: In 1965 and 1967 some changes were officially introduced into the Mass of the Roman Rite in the wake of Sacrosanctum Concilium, but no new edition of the Roman Missal had been produced to incorporate them.

A13.text: Promulgation of the Roman Missal Revised by Decree of the Second Vatican Council, 1969

A14.text: General Instruction of the Roman Missal of 2002 Latin text, free from adaptations for particular countries

A15.text: The council fathers established guidelines to govern the renewal of the liturgy, which included, allowed, and encouraged greater use of the vernacular (native language) in addition to Latin, particularly for the biblical readings, intercessions, and other prayers.

A16.text: Implementation of the council's directives on the liturgy was to be carried out under the authority of Pope Paul VI by a special papal commission known as the Council for the Implementation of the Constitution on the Sacred Liturgy (or the Consilium for short), later incorporated in the Congregation for Divine Worship and the Discipline of the Sacraments, and, in the areas entrusted to them, by national conferences of bishops, which, if they had a shared language, were expected to collaborate in producing a common translation.

A17.text: In 2007 Pope Benedict XVI gave general permission to priests of the Latin Church to use either the 1962 Missal or the post‑Vatican II Missal both privately and, under certain conditions, publicly.

A18.text: Within four years of the close of the council, Paul VI promulgated in 1969 the first postconciliar edition, which included three new Eucharistic Prayers in addition to the Roman Canon, until then the only anaphora in the Roman Rite.

A19.text: allowing the Mass to be said in the vernacular (local language)

A20.text: The present ordinary form of Mass in the Roman Rite, found in the post‑1969 editions of the Roman Missal, is usually celebrated in the local vernacular language, using an officially approved translation from the original text in Latin.
